qas.question: What permanent group representative do hunter-gatherers not have?
Initiative within the group depends upon what factor?
What group arrangement is usual in family authority?
What is the kinship and decent system among hunter-gatherers?
Who maintains that hunter/gatherers have permanent leaders?
Where is there often sexual disparity?
Young mothers get no child support from whom?

plausible_answers.text: kinship and descent among human hunter-gatherers

context: <b5_0>Anthropologists<b5_0/> maintain that <b4_0>hunter/gatherers<b4_0/> don't have <a0_0>permanent leaders<a0_0/>; instead, the person taking the initiative at any one time depends on the <a1_0>task being performed<a1_0/>. In addition to social and economic equality in <b6_0>hunter-gatherer societies<b6_0/>, there is often, though not always, sexual parity as well. Hunter-gatherers are often grouped together based on kinship and band (or tribe) membership. Postmarital residence among hunter-gatherers tends to be <a2_0>matrilocal<a2_0/>, at least initially. Young mothers can enjoy childcare support from <b7_0>their own mothers<b7_0/>, who continue living nearby in the same camp. The systems of <b8_0>kinship and descent among human hunter-gatherers<b8_0/> were relatively flexible, although there is evidence that early human kinship in general tended to be <a3_0>matrilineal<a3_0/>.
